About.name: University of Brighton
About.about:
At the University of Brighton, you’ll study in the independent and inclusive beachside city of Brighton & Hove, and gain more than just a degree. We offer over 150 undergraduate courses, all designed with your future in mind.
The city is a great place for students to open doors to their dream career. Courses involve opportunities to get involved in work-related experiences, including placements, study abroad, live project briefs or assessed voluntary work. The University’s employability hub supports students to find work while studying and after graduation.
About.whatMakesUsDifferent:
Brighton is a place where everyone belongs and it is in the top 5 UK cities in the world (2025 Time Out Worlds 50 Best Cities in the World rankings). Its diversity shines through in the shops, cafes, parades, nightlife and arts scene and it has a great student community.
Living in Brighton has a positive effect on wellbeing; there’s an undeniable feel-good factor of being on the coast, from the fun of sunny beach days to quieter times with that soothing 180 degrees of open water.
Students also benefit from its proximity to London and nearby seaside cities and villages, which make it a brilliant place to call home while exploring beyond Brighton.
At Brighton, students form connections and learn the skills and knowledge to continue the path to their dream career. Each and every degree is built with employability in mind, incorporating vocational and practical training to ensure students graduate with the skills that employers are looking for.

Stats.heading: Stats
Stats.description: Statistics and reviews are supplied by trusted partners and are independent to UCAS. You should also consider attending an open day and talking to staff and students.

StudentLife.heading: Student life
studentLifeParagraphs: Life as a Brighton student will be full of chances to explore new things, learn new skills and make new connections.

Whether students are into city-living or prefer an outdoor lifestyle, they can experience it all in Brighton. In addition to the beach, countryside and nightclubs, there are also fantastic independent shops and cafes in the famous Brighton Lanes, which is a great place to socialise over a coffee and admire the colourful houses and street art.

Students can socialise through over 100 student-led clubs and societies run by Brighton Students' Union and there are over 60 sports clubs (social and competitve) for those interested in sports and exercise.

regionGuides.heading: What's it like to live in South East?Check out our region guide
paragraphs: South East England is made up of nine counties, with popular student cities in Brighton & Hove, Oxford, Portsmouth, Reading, and Southampton.
The area sees plenty of sunshine and Brighton – the LGBTQ+ capital of the UK – is a student favourite, with tons of quirky shops, cafes, arts, nightlife and watersports.

Moving east into Kent, you'll find the charming towns of Whitstable, Broadstairs, and Margate – all bursting with literary history – plus the iconic landmarks of Dover’s white cliffs and Canterbury Cathedral.

London is an hour or two away for gigs, theatre trips and capital city adventures, while the country’s two largest airports – Heathrow and Gatwick – mean international journeys are easy to get started.

regionGuides.heading: What's it like to live in Brighton?Check out our city guide
paragraphs: Discover what it’s really like to live in Brighton – from seaside strolls and independent shops to thriving nightlife and inclusive student life.

campusParagraphs: There are three campuses across the city, each within easy reach of the beach, city and libraries.

The University has invested over £100 million has on facilities over the last decade. This includes state-of-the-art seminar rooms, lecture theatres, labs, studio spaces, exhibition spaces, and workshops.

Moulsecoomb campus was recently redeveloped and it is now home to a new gym with the latest equipment and a studio with a programme of classes. It’s also home to the new Students’ Union, new halls of residence and improved infrastructure.
Falmer has newly renovated gym and the indoor swimming pool was opened in 2025, in addition to outdoor facilities including grass pitches, a floodlit 3G pitch and hardcourts.

City campus is home to the art, design and media courses and is based in the heart of Brighton - a short stroll from the famous Brighton beach and pier. You’ll have access to specialist facilities, galleries, studios and more.

Courses.heading: Courses
paragraphs: The University of Brighton is home to over 150 undergraduate courses and over 120 postgraduate courses, each with built-in vocational training including placements, live project briefs, study abroad and more. Brighton encourages students to tailor their courses to fit their career goals while studying in a way that plays to their strengths.

The University of Brighton is in the top 3rd in the UK for employment or further study, three years after graduating (Longitudinal Education Outcomes 2021/22). This is testament to the University’s teaching quality and strong graduate outcomes.
Students can boost their CV while studying through:

Apprenticeships.heading: Apprenticeships
paragraphs: Since 2016, the University of Brighton has been developing and delivering higher and degree apprenticeships at level 5, 6 and 7, equivalent to foundation, bachelors and masters degrees. Apprentices combine work with part-time university study and develop through on-the-job learning with work-based projects relevant to their organisation.

The University offers apprenticeships in construction and engineering, health and science, and education Apprenticeships are a great option for those looking to enter the world of work with a CV full of experience and theoretical knowledge that employers look for.

International.heading: International
paragraphs: In the QS 2025 rankings for Best Student Cities, Brighton is in the top 100 worldwide, in addition to being ranked in the top 5 UK cities in the world (2025 Time Out Worlds 50 Best Cities in the World).

With Brighton, you’ll go further: 50 professional organisations recognise the university’s courses and the University was awarded TEF Silver, demonstrating the quality of its teaching and student outcomes.

Courses at Brighton develop the qualities, characteristics and skills that employers are looking for so students graduate feeling confident about stepping into the world of work after graduation. Throughout their degree, students have access to careers advice and support.

The University and the city are inclusive and welcoming. Students who join Brighton become part of a global community focused on positive change. Students can create even more connections by joining societies to do with their academic subject, faith, and leisurely interests.

"Brighton is vibrant, multicultural, and inclusive, both as a university and a city. During this time in my life, I met people from all different walks of life and yet we all had so much in common. I learnt about different cultures and am still in touch with many of my international university friends today." - Shirin Alwash, Pharmacy MPharm

StudentSupport.heading: Student support
paragraphs: Student mental health, wellbeing, and safety is of paramount importance to the University of Brighton. Diversity and inclusion are at the centre of all of Brighton’s activities and the University offers a range of support services designed to help students from the day they arrive on campus.

All students have access to a Student Support and Guidance Tutor (SSGT) and a Personal Academic Tutor (PAT). SSGTs are dedicated to supporting any issues that might be impacting studies, wellbeing or experience. PATs provide academic advice and work closely with the SSGTs to ensure that students are supported holistically.

For students who want to work while they study, there are opportunities to apply for paid roles on campus. The careers and employability team can provide advice on finding a job in the city, and answer career-related questions.
